docs.lead_paragraph: CHATTING with reporters on the last night of his trip to Africa last month, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill suggested that he was returning home a changed man. Having spent the better part of two weeks getting an up-close look at intense poverty and its victims, Mr. O'Neill said no one could have been unaffected by the experience.

headline.main: Middle Path Emerges In Debate On Africa Aid

docs.abstract: Richard W Stevenson Economic View column considers possibility that recent visit by Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill and musician Bono to assess poverty in Africa might result in sustained United States commitment to making foreign aid efficacious; table of numerous countries' relative foreign development aid contributions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: US Airways and its unions negotiated throughout the week on concessions by workers, but labor leaders said they were dissatisfied with the carrier's proposals. The airline has said it wants the unions to agree to concessions by next Saturday so it can apply for $1 billion in federal loan guarantees. David N. Siegel, the chief executive of US Airways, is seeking to cut $950 million in annual labor costs as part of a revamping plan. The airline must submit that plan to the federal government by June 28, the deadline to apply for loan guarantees under the $10 billion program set up by Congress after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: US Airways and Unions Fail to Agree on Concessions

docs.abstract: US Airways and its union negotiate on concessions by workers, but labor leaders say they are dissatisfied with carrier's proposals; airline has said it wants unions to agree to concessions by June 15 so it can apply for $1 billion in federal loan guarantees; David N Siegel, chief exec, seeks to cut $950 million in annual labor costs as part of revamping plan; photo (M)0

docs.lead_paragraph: Offering a glint of hope to out-of-work Americans and further evidence of an improving economy, the unemployment rate fell to 5.8 percent in May, from 6 percent in April. But an unimpressive gain of just 41,000 in the number of people on business payrolls -- often considered a more reliable measure of current conditions than the unemployment rate -- led experts to caution that the nascent economic recovery is unlikely to produce many new jobs until businesses start investing again.

headline.main: Jobless Rate Fell 0.2 Point Last Month

docs.abstract: Labor Dept reports that unemployment rate fell to 5.8 percent in May from 6 percent in April, offering glint of hope to out-of-work Americans and further evidence of improving economy; reports that number of long-term unemployed rose to 1.64 million last month; report follows series of encouraging indicators about economy this week; report ushers in new measures of employment in several service industries; new statistics incoporate probability-based estimates as well as hard data; tables, graphs on employment; chart shows consumer borrowing (M)
